title: From Phorritos to Bone Broth — A Local Culinary Star Opens a New Indonesian Restaurant
text:
The Best Kosher Corridor Restaurants, According to MexiKosher Chef Katsuji Tanabe 
Also, to share: beef tartare, brightened with fish sauce instead of citrus. It's a textural blend of fried and fresh shallot, Japanese silken mayo, and a Thai basil and chive garnish. Accompanying it is a garlic onion chip for crunch. 
And finally, the suggested main course: beef rendang. “Traditional beef rendang is braised beef cooked in a wok for forty-eight hours,” Tjahyadi says. Traditionally, the result looks like dry rubbed meat with nary a drop of liquid. In his take on the dish, Tjahyadi sous vides short rib for eighteen hours. 
For those less familiar with Indonesian cuisine, he gives us a little backstory. 
"A lot of flavors are bolder and stronger and are right in your face than Vietnamese and Cambodian flavors. A lot of other East Asian [foods] are more subtle and let herbs speak for themselves," he explains. "We tend to heavy cook our meat and heavy cook our vegetables. A lot of braising, a lot of long time cooking, a lot of spices. When you taste [the food], it’s so overwhelming that you have to eat it with white rice to complement. 
"We use a lot of turmeric, galangal and kaffir lime. Kaffir lime leaves, they’re like using lime zest but ten times stronger; so concentrated. We use a lot of calamansi instead of lime. It’s like a mixture of kumquat and lime.” Bone Kettle interior. Dylan + Jeni 
If this is intriguing, let your education continue at Bone Kettle. Tjahyadi says he's looking forward to stretching his legs a bit with the new restaurant. Although he’s enjoyed enormous success with Komodo, which will soon have three locations, he welcomes a change from the limitations of the fast-casual concept. 
"I feel like I can be more creative with Bone Kettle, menu-wise. With Komodo, people are pretty set with their mind. They want to come eat tacos and burritos, so you can only experiment so much ... at Bone Kettle, I’m going to be able to change the menu every three months.” 
67 North Raymond Ave., Pasadena, (626) 795-5702, bonekettle.com .
